timeline.message:
Revisit RH references in StringResource_en_US.xml files

TODO:
- RHNMD?
- RHN Applet?

Affected java packages: jsp and java

This XPath was used for searching the strings:
//source[contains(lower-case(text()), "rhn") and not(contains(lower-case(text()), "/rhn"))] | //source[contains(lower-case(text()), "satellite")]| //source[contains(lower-case(text()), "red hat")]
Revisit RH references in Python/Ruby localization

timeline.bodyText:
Red Hat Network != Uyuni Server
Red Hat Network is more like SCC. But I think this message is in a code path we may not use
timeline.author: mcalmer
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -19,77 +19,76 @@
 COPYRIGHT_TEXT        = _(u"Copyright © 2006--2014 Red Hat, Inc. All rights reserved.")
 
 # Satellite URL Window
-SATELLITE_URL_WINDOW  = _("Enter your Red Hat Satellite URL.")
-SATELLITE_URL_TEXT    = _("Please enter the location of your Red Hat Satellite "
+SATELLITE_URL_WINDOW  = _("Enter your Uyuni URL.")
+SATELLITE_URL_TEXT    = _("Please enter the location of your Uyuni "
                           "server and of its SSL "
                           "certificate. The SSL certificate is only required "
                           "if you will be connecting over https (recommended).")
-SATELLITE_URL_PROMPT  = _("Satellite URL:")
+SATELLITE_URL_PROMPT  = _("Uyuni URL:")
 SATELLITE_URL_PROMPT2 = _("SSL certificate:")
-SATELLITE_REQUIRED    = _("You must enter a valid Satellite URL.")
+SATELLITE_REQUIRED    = _("You must enter a valid Uyuni URL.")
 SSL_REQUIRED          = _("If you are using https you must enter the location "
                           "of a valid SSL certificate.")
 
 # Connect Window
 CONNECT_WINDOW        = _("Attempting to contact the Spacewalk server.")
-CONNECT_WINDOW_TEXT   = _("We are attempting to contact the Red Hat "
-                          "Network server at %s.")
+CONNECT_WINDOW_TEXT   = _("We are attempting to contact the Uyuni "
+                          "server at %s.")

replies.bodyText:
This message is used in the TUI interface of the up2date_client (when user runs rhn_register): https://github.com/uyuni-project/uyuni/blob/master/client/rhel/spacewalk-client-tools/src/up2date_client/tui.py#L334
To me it looks like Uyuni/Spacewalk/Satellite/SUSE Manager is contacted here, not the RHN/SCC, so I think the change is correct.
replies.author: hustodemon

replies.bodyText:
The problem is, RHN is a hosted version of Satellite. So it is hard to know if this apply also to Uyuni, or they request a task which can be done only in SCC when we talk about SUSE.
Ok with me.
replies.author: mcalmer

timeline.bodyText: RHN != Uyuni
timeline.author: mcalmer
timeline.diffHunk:

replies.bodyText:
Again, this is in used in rhn_register and I think Uyuni is the correct entity here. When you click the button Why should I connect to RHN, you get a list of advantages of registering to satellite.
See the screenshot:

after clicking:
replies.author: hustodemon

replies.bodyText: ok
replies.author: mcalmer

replies.bodyText:
I think Uyuni/SUMA is correct here: if you read the whole message, I believe "they" are making reference to Satellite UI:

"Contact your Uyuni administrator about this problem. Once you make the "
"appropriate active subscriptions available in your account, you may browse "
"to this system's profile in the Uyuni web interface and subscribe this system "
"to software channels via the software > software channels tab.")
replies.author: hustodemon

replies.bodyText: ok
replies.author: mcalmer

timeline.bodyText: Not sure what RHN modules are. AFAIK we do not have something like this in SCC. Not sure what to do with this message

replies.bodyText: Hm, after studying the source, it seems that slots are entitlements system types and this message pops up when user runs out of them (shouldn't happen in SUMA/Uyuni).

timeline.bodyText: No idea what "service level modules" are. I think we do not have them. rename this to Uyuni ... might not be a good idea

timeline.message: Review comments in the python part
Review comments in the java part

timeline.bodyText:
We should either use "...from another Server" or have a PRODUCT_NAME replacement in Python like the one we have in Java. We should not say "Uyuni", that will puzzle downstream (SUSE Manager) users.
See my PR 2 weeks ago for details on replacement variables:
#2575

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                                      "use the cdn-sync command instead unless you are attempting to sync from another Uyuni "
          
          
            
                                      "use the cdn-sync command instead unless you are attempting to sync from another Server "
timeline.author: paususe
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -532,8 +532,8 @@ def initialize(self):
             else:
                 log(1, _(PRODUCT_NAME + ' - live synchronization'))
                 log(-1, _("ERROR: Live content synchronizing with RHN Classic Hosted is no longer supported.\nPlease "
-                          "use the cdn-sync command instead unless you are attempting to sync from another Satellite "
-                          "via Inter-Satelite-Sync (ISS), or from local content on disk via Channel Dump ISOs."),
+                          "use the cdn-sync command instead unless you are attempting to sync from another Uyuni "

replies.bodyText: Yes - your PR only has the placeholders for java, afaik. But not for python.
replies.author: hustodemon

timeline.bodyText:
Is this string even used these days? I'm surprised this string is in the Python code but not in https://github.com/uyuni-project/uyuni/blob/master/client/rhel/spacewalk-client-tools/po/rhn-client-tools.pot
Maybe our string-extraction is not looking at this "firstboot-legay-rhel5" directory? Should it? According to the Makefile in that directory, that installs "man pages for the up2date client". Do we use the up2date  client at all?

+    moduleName = _("Login")

+    shortMessage = _("Register with Uyuni")

Is this string even used these days?

Do we use the up2date client at all?

AFAIK yes. up2date client is the traditional stack.
